question.text: The stability of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> is more than <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></math> salts in aqueous solution due to -

solution.text: The stability of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>(</mo><mi>aq</mi><mo>)</mo></math> rather than <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo> </mo><mo>(</mo><mi>aq</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is due to the much more negative <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mo>∆</mo><mi>hyd</mi></msub><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></msup></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>(</mo><mi>aq</mi><mo>)</mo></math> than <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo> </mo></math>, which more than compensates for the second ionisation enthalpy of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Cu</mi></math>. The <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> ion has a greater charge density than <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></math> ion and thus forms much stronger bonds releasing more hydration energy.
